    ACT: Paragraph 1(m) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act
     
    REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars

    Which best describes the bars?

    Meal replacement bars are bars that qualify as meal replacements or nutritional supplements under the Food and Drugs Act and Regulations.

    Cereal bars and muffin bars - A cereal bar with a fruit filling is generally not considered to be a fruit bar.

    • Meal replacement bars
    • Cereal bars and muffin bars
    • Energy bars and protein bars
    • Granola bars, fruit bars or nut bars
    • Chocolate bars other other candy bars
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
    4. Which best describes the bars? – Meal replacement bars

    RESULT: Zero-rated

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    • GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries
    • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-020, Bars

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
    4. Which best describes the bars? – Cereal bars and muffin bars

    How are the bars packaged?

    • Six or more bars in a box
    • Sold individually (or less than six bars in a box)

    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
    4. Which best describes the bars? – Cereal bars and muffin bars
    5. How are the bars packaged? – Six or more bars in a box

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCES:

    • GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries
    • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-020, Bars

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses

    4. Which best describes the bars? – Granola bars, fruit bars or nut bars

    EXCEPTION: Granola products sold as cereals are zero-rated

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCES:

    • GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries
    • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-020, Bars

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Protein bars, chocolate bars or snack bars
    4. Which best describes the bars? – Chocolate bars other other candy bars

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    EXCEPTION: Fondue chocolate that is traditionally supplied in bar form (170 to 200 grams) in the baking section of grocery stores is zero-rated. However, if the chocolate bars are sold as fondue chocolate for fund-raising purposes (usually door-to-door sales), they are no longer zero-rated

    ACT: Paragraphs 1(e) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    • GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries
    • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-020, Bars


    EXAMPLES:

    • chocolate or candy bars
    • sesame bars and other fruits, seeds, nuts or popcorn when coated or treated with candy, chocolate, honey, molasses, sugar, syrup or artificial sweeteners

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Pudding, ice cream, yogurt or similar items

    Which best describes the grocery item?

    • Pudding, flavoured gelatine, mousse or similar items
    • Ice cream, sherbert, frozen yogurt, or non-dairy versions

    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Pudding, ice cream, yogurt or similar items
    4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Pudding, flavoured gelatine, mousse or similar items

    Which best describes the grocery item?

    Single serving, for puddings and similar products, includes all servings weighing less than 425 grams.

    • Single serving
    • Larger than a single serving
    • Multiple single servings (prepackaged)
    • Prepared and prepackaged for consumption by babies

    4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Pudding, flavoured gelatine, mousse or similar items
    5. Which best describes the grocery item? – Single serving

    ACT: Paragraph 1(n) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages
    • GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Pudding, ice cream, yogurt or similar items
    4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Ice cream, sherbert, frozen yogurt, or non-dairy versions

    Which best describes the grocery item?

    Single serving - includes cones, sundaes, cups, dishes, bowls or similar containers.

    "Single serving", for these purposes, includes packages containing multiples of single servings.

    Larger than single serving - includes packages containing at least 500 ml or 500 grams (when packaged at the retail level for home consumption).

    • Single serving
    • Larger than single serving
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Pudding, ice cream, yogurt or similar items
    4. Which best describes the grocery item? – Ice cream, sherbert, frozen yogurt, or non-dairy versions
    5. Which best describes the grocery item? – Single serving

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks

    To make the drink, is the syrup, crystal or powder added to water or to milk?

    • Added to water
    • Added to milk or milk alternatives
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - syrups, crystals, powders or tea bags
    4. To make the drink, is the syrup, crystal or powder added to water or to milk? – Added to water

    Which best describes the drink?

    • Coffee or tea
    • Protein shake
    • Fruit-flavoured drink
    • None of the above
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - syrups, crystals, powders or tea bags
    4. To make the drink, is the syrup, crystal or powder added to water or to milk? – Added to water
    5. Which best describes the drink? – Coffee or tea

    RESULT: Zero-rated

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

    EXAMPLES:

    • instant coffee
    • tea
    • iced tea
    • fruit-flavoured iced tea

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - syrups, crystals, powders or tea bags
    4. To make the drink, is the syrup, crystal or powder added to water or to milk? – Added to water
    5. Which best describes the drink? – Protein shake

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate dietary supplements since, although they may contain some essential nutritional elements, they are generally taken for their therapeutic or beneficial effects and are not considered to be basic groceries.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - syrups, crystals, powders or tea bags
    4. To make the drink, is the syrup, crystal or powder added to water or to milk? – Added to water
    5. Which best describes the drink? – Fruit-flavoured drink

    Which best describes the fruit-flavoured drink?

    • Fruit-flavoured tea
    • 25% or more natural fruit juice
    • Less than 25% natural fruit juice
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Drinks - syrups, crystals, powders or tea bags
    4. To make the drink, is the syrup, crystal or powder added to water or to milk? – Added to water
    5. Which best describes the drink? – Fruit-flavoured drink
    6. Which best describes the fruit-flavoured drink? – Fruit-flavoured tea

    RESULT: Zero-rated

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

    • lemon-flavoured iced tea powder

    RESULT: Zero-rated

    ACT: Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

    EXAMPLE:

    • strawberry-flavoured syrup that is added to milk to make a drink (even though it is fruit flavoured, it is not added to water to form the drink so it is zero-rated)

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption

    Which best describes the situation?

    • Catering
    • Sandwich
    • Restaurant meal
    • Drink - Dispensed where sold
    • Heated for immediate consumption
    • Frozen foods or other foods needing to be cooked
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
    4. Which best describes the situation? – Catering

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    EXCEPTION: Certain specific situations where the food is frozen or otherwise needs to be cooked

    ACT: Paragraph (o.5) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    EXAMPLES:

    • banquet halls
    • on-site catering
    • food trays delivered to an office

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
    4. Which best describes the situation? – Sandwich

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    EXCEPTION: When sold frozen

    ACT: Paragraph 1(o.2) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    EXAMPLES:

    • paninis
    • wraps
    • hamburgers
    • hot dogs

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
    4. Which best describes the situation? – Restaurant meal

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT: Paragraph 1(o) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    EXAMPLES:

    • eat-in meal at a restaurant
    • fast-food take-out
    • cafeteria meal

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
    4. Which best describes the situation? – Drink - Dispensed where sold

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:  Paragraph 1(o.4) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Info Sheet GI-036, Beverages

    EXAMPLES: All drinks when dispensed where sold, regardless of size and whether hot or cold, including:

    • tea
    • coffee
    • pop
    • juice

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
    4. Which best describes the situation? – Heated for immediate consumption

    RESULT: Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT: Paragraph 1(o) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act excludes from zero-rating all food or drinks that have been heated for immediate consumption

    EXAMPLES:

    • Hot coffee or tea
    • Food or drinks sold from a heated cabinet
    • Food or drinks sold from a separate take-out counter
    • Food or drinks bought and then heated at the point of purchase

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Food or drinks
    3. Which best describes the food or drink? – Catering, restaurant or other immediate consumption
    4. Which best describes the situation? – Frozen foods or other foods needing to be cooked

    RESULT: Certain frozen foods or other foods that are not prepared for immediate consumption may be zero-rated even when sold at a restaurant or other similar establishment

    ACT: Section 1(q) of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE: GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Personal services

    RESULT:

    Haircuts, manicures and other similar personal services are taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. For zero-rated status of services such as acupuncture or chiropractic services, see Healthcare services.

    ACT:
    There are no provisions in Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act that apply specifically to make personal services GST/HST exempt.

    There are no provisions in Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act that apply specifically to make personal services zero-rated for GST/HST purposes.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods

    Which best describes the retail goods being sold?

    • Finished - Clothing and shoes
    • Finished - Musical instrument
    • Finished - Home and garden items
    • Finished - Feminine hygiene products
    • Finished - Printed books, newspapers and magazines
    • Finished - Face mask or face shield designed for human use
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Clothing and shoes

    Which option describes the clothing or shoes being supplied?

    Clothing and footwear are generally taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. However, there are exceptions for certain types of specially designed clothing and footwear. 

    • Finished - Specially designed clothing
    • Finished - Specially designed footwear
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Clothing and shoes
    4. Which option describes the clothing or shoes being supplied? – Finished - Specially designed clothing

    RESULT:

    A supply of clothing is zero-rated if it is supplied on the written order of a medical practitioner and is specially designed for use by an individual with a disability, regardless of who initially receives the supply.

    ACT:

    Section 36 of Part II of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.2, Medical and Assistive Devices

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Clothing and shoes
    4. Which option describes the clothing or shoes being supplied? – Finished - Specially designed footwear

    RESULT:

    A supply of footwear (for example, shoes, boots, sneakers or loafers) is zero-rated if it is supplied on the written order of a medical practitioner and is specially designed for use by an individual with a crippled or deformed foot or other similar disability.

    ACT:

    Section 24.1 of Part II of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.2, Medical and Assistive Devices

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Musical instrument

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    There are no provisions in Schedule V or Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act that apply specifically to make the supply of musical instruments GST/HST exempt or zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Home and garden items

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    There are no provisions in Schedule V or Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act that apply specifically to make the supply of home or garden items GST/HST exempt or zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Feminine hygiene products

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    ACT:

    Section 1 of Part II.I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLES:

    • sanitary napkin
    • tampon
    • sanitary belt
    • menstrual cup
    • other similar product that is marketed exclusively for feminine hygiene purposes

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Printed books, newspapers and magazines

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. However, a tax rebate is available under certain circumstances.

    ACT:

    Although there are no provisions in the Excise Tax Act (ETA) that apply specifically to make the supply of printed books GST/HST exempt or zero-rated, subsection 259.1(2) of the ETA allows for a tax rebate in certain circumstances.  

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 13.4, Rebates for Printed Books, Audio Recordings of Printed Books, and Printed Versions of Religious Scriptures

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Face mask or face shield designed for human use

    Which option describes the face mask or face shield being supplied?

    • Finished - Face shield
    • Finished - N95, KN95 or equivalent
    • Finished - Other face mask or respirator
    • Finished - Face mask or respirator authorized for medical use in Canada
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Face mask or face shield designed for human use
    4. Which option describes the face mask or face shield being supplied? – Finished - Face shield

    RESULT:

    Unless the face shield is specifically designed or marketed for a use other than preventing the transmission of infectious agents such as respiratory viruses, its supply is zero-rated if both of the following conditions have been met:

    • has a transparent and impermeable window or visor
    • covers the entire face and has a head strap or cap for holding it in place

    Legislation also zero-rates a prescribed face shiled but there are currently none prescribed.

    ACT:

    Section 5 of Part II.I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Face mask or face shield designed for human use
    4. Which option describes the face mask or face shield being supplied? – Finished - N95, KN95 or equivalent

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the face mask or respirator meets N95, KN95 or equivalent certification requirements and does not have an exhalation valve or vent.

    ACT:

    Section 3 of Part II.I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Face mask or face shield designed for human use
    4. Which option describes the face mask or face shield being supplied? – Finished - Other face mask or respirator

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the face mask or respirator meets all of the following conditions:

    • for use in preventing the transmission of infectious agents such as respiratory viruses
    • large enough to completely cover the nose, mouth and chin without gaping
    • has ear loops, ties or straps for securing it to the head
    • made of multiple layers of dense material (but may have a portion in front of the lips made of transparent and impermeable material that permits lip reading provided that there is a tight seal between the transparent material and the rest of the face mask or respirator)
    • does not have an exhalation valve or vent

    Legislation also zero-rates a prescribed mask or respirator but there are currently none prescribed.

    ACT:

    Section 4 of Part II.I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Other retail goods
    3. Which best describes the retail goods being sold? – Finished - Face mask or face shield designed for human use
    4. Which option describes the face mask or face shield being supplied? – Finished - Face mask or respirator authorized for medical use in Canada

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part II.I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Healthcare services

    Which best describes the healthcare service?

    Meaning of practitioner

    In respect of a supply of optometric, chiropractic, physiotherapy, chiropodic, podiatric, osteopathic, audiological, speech-language pathology, occupational therapy, psychological, midwifery, dietetic, acupuncture or naturopathic services, the term practitioner means a person who:

    • practises the profession of optometry, chiropractic, physiotherapy, chiropody, podiatry, osteopathy, audiology, speech-language pathology, occupational therapy, psychology, midwifery, dietetics, acupuncture or naturopathy as a naturopathic doctor, as the case may be,
    • where the person is required to be licensed or otherwise certified to practise the profession in the province in which the service is supplied, is so licensed or certified, and
    • where the person is not required to be licensed or otherwise certified to practise the profession in that province, has the qualifications equivalent to those necessary to be so licensed or otherwise certified in another province.

    • Finished - Nursing
    • Finished - Podiatry
    • Finished - Audiology
    • Finished - Osteopathy
    • Finished - Psychology
    • Finished - Acupuncture
    • Finished - Physiotherapy
    • Finished - Medical doctor
    • Finished - Dental services
    • Finished - Midwife services
    • Finished - Dietetic services
    • Finished - Home care service
    • Finished - Naturopathic doctor
    • Finished - Occupational therapy
    • Finished - Chiropractic services
    • Finished - Speech-language pathology
    • Finished - Registered massage therapy
    • Finished - Health care service reimbursed by provincial government health care plan
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Healthcare services
    3. Which best describes the healthcare service? – Finished - Nursing

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt if the service is rendered to an individual by a registered nurse, a registered nursing assistant, a licensed or registered practical nurse or a registered psychiatric nurse, if the service is rendered within a nurse-patient relationship.

    ACT:

    Section 6 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Healthcare services
    3. Which best describes the healthcare service? – Finished - Podiatry

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt if the service is rendered to an individual by a practitioner of the service

    Is the service performed for cosmetic purposes and not for medical or reconstructive purposes?

    • Yes
    • No

    2. What is being supplied? – Healthcare services

    4. Is the service performed for cosmetic purposes and not for medical or reconstructive purposes? – Yes

    RESULT:

    GST/HST taxable

    Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not contain an exemption

    4. Is the service performed for cosmetic purposes and not for medical or reconstructive purposes? – No

    GST/HST taxable

    Section 5 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not apply as an exemption

    2. What is being supplied? – Healthcare services
    3. Which best describes the healthcare service? – Finished - Dietetic services
    4. Is the dietetic service rendered to an individual? – No
    5. Is the dietetic service made to a public sector body or to the operator of a health care facility? – No

    GST/HST taxable

    ACT:

    Section 7.1 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Healthcare services
    3. Which best describes the healthcare service? – Finished - Home care service

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt if the service is rendered to an individual in the individual's place of residence and one of the following three circumstances apply:

    1. The supplier is a government or municipality.
    2. A government, municipality or organization administering a government or municipal program in respect of home care services pays an amount to:
      • the supplier in respect of the supply
      • any person for the purpose of the acquisition of the service
    3. Another supply of a home care service rendered to the individual is made in the circumstances described in either 1 or 2 above.

    ACT:

    Section 13 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    ACT:

    Section 9 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act  

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services

    What is the type of educational service being supplied?

    For university, public college, vocational school, or other school services, see the topic "Municipality, university, school or hospital" instead

    • Tutoring
    • Educational services made to a non-resident
    • Private music lessons supplied to an individual
    • Second language instruction in English or French
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Tutoring

    What type of course is the individual being tutored in?

    GST/HST exemption for supplies of tutoring services does not apply in a situation where the tutor has negligible interaction with the student because the tutoring method is based on self-learning exercises or activities (for example, games) that strengthen a variety of cognitive skills.

    • A course where its successful completion is mandatory for admittance into a music course
    • A course that is approved for credit by, or that follows a curriculum designated by, a school authority
    • A course where its successful completion is mandatory for admittance into a course that is approved for credit by, or that follows a curriculum designated by, a school authority
    • Other
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Tutoring
    4. What type of course is the individual being tutored in? – A course where its successful completion is mandatory for admittance into a music course

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt if it is an immediate prerequisite course, but earlier levels that are not mandatory for admittance into an exempt course are not exempt

    ACT:

    Paragraph 9(c) of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.6, Tutoring and Equivalent Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Tutoring
    4. What type of course is the individual being tutored in? – A course that is approved for credit by, or that follows a curriculum designated by, a school authority

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    ACT:

    Paragraph 9(a) of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.6, Tutoring and Equivalent Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Tutoring
    4. What type of course is the individual being tutored in? – A course where its successful completion is mandatory for admittance into a course that is approved for credit by, or that follows a curriculum designated by, a school authority

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt if it is an immediate prerequisite course, but earlier levels that are not mandatory for admittance into an exempt course are not exempt

    ACT:

    Paragraph 9(c) of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.6, Tutoring and Equivalent Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Tutoring
    4. What type of course is the individual being tutored in? – Other

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 9 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act does not exempt the supply in this situation

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.6, Tutoring and Equivalent Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident

    Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident
    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes

    Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident
    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes
    5. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply in this situation.

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.8, Educational Services Made to a Non-resident

    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services

    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes
    5. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual? – No

    Is the non-resident the supply is being made to a GST/HST registrant?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident
    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes
    5. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual? – No
    6. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to a GST/HST registrant? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply in this situation.

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.8, Educational Services Made to a Non-resident

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident
    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes
    5. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual? – No
    6. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to a GST/HST registrant? – No

    Does the supply consist of a service of instructing non-resident individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, certain courses? These courses must lead to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of the individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident
    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes
    5. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual? – No
    6. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to a GST/HST registrant? – No
    7. Does the supply consist of a service of instructing non-resident individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, certain courses? These courses must lead to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of the individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    ACT:

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.8, Educational Services Made to a Non-resident

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Educational services made to a non-resident
    4. Is the supply a service of instructing non-resident individuals? – Yes
    5. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to also an individual? – No
    6. Is the non-resident the supply is being made to a GST/HST registrant? – No
    7. Does the supply consist of a service of instructing non-resident individuals in, or administering examinations in respect of, certain courses? These courses must lead to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents, or classes or ratings in respect of licences, that attest to the competence of the individuals to practise or perform a trade or vocation. – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply in this situation.

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.8, Educational Services Made to a Non-resident

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply in this situation.

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.8, Educational Services Made to a Non-resident

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Private music lessons supplied to an individual

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    ACT:

    • Paragraph 9(b) of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
    • Section 2 of the Equivalent Courses (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.6, Tutoring and Equivalent Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Second language instruction in English or French

    Who is supplying the language instruction?

    • A university, public college, vocational school, or school authority
    • A business established and operated primarily to provide instruction in languages
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Second language instruction in English or French
    4. Who is supplying the language instruction? – A university, public college, vocational school, or school authority

    See the topic "Municipality, university, school or hospital" instead

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Educational services
    3. What is the type of educational service being supplied? – Second language instruction in English or French
    4. Who is supplying the language instruction? – A business established and operated primarily to provide instruction in languages

    RESULT:

    Their supplies of services of instructing individuals in English and French as a second language are GST/HST exempt

    ACT:

    Section 11 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 20.7, Second-language Instruction

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services

    Which best describes the transportation service?

    • Road and bridge tolls
    • Freight transportation
    • Passenger transportation
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Road and bridge tolls

    RESULT:

    A supply of a right to use a road or bridge where a toll is charged for that right is GST/HST exempt

    ACT:
    Section 2 of Part VIII of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.1, Ferries, Toll Roads and Toll Bridges

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation

    Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service?

    • Finished - Interlining
    • Finished - Stevedoring
    • Finished - Reload centre
    • Finished - Towing services
    • Finished - Shunting services
    • Finished - Sufferance warehouses
    • Finished - Supply by a non-resident
    • Finished - Postage and mail delivery
    • Finished - Freight forwarders' services
    • Finished - Settlement paid for loss or damage
    • Finished - Supply to an international carrier
    • Finished - Supplies by agents to non-residents
    • Finished - Rolling stock penalties and demurrage
    • Finished - International freight transportation services
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Interlining

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated freight transportation service

    DEFINITION:
    Several carriers may participate in the supply of a freight transportation service in the course of a continuous freight movement from the origin of the freight movement to its destination, where only one carrier invoices the shipper or consignee. Where this occurs, the carriers participating in the movement are considered to be interlining.

    ACT:
    Subsection 1(2) of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Stevedoring

    RESULT:

    Stevedoring is considered to be a freight transportation service when it is part of or incidental to a freight transportation service.

    Generally, domestic freight transportation services are taxable at 5%, 13%, or 15% and international freight transportation services are zero-rated.

    DEFINITION:
    Stevedoring is the loading and unloading of ships. Persons providing services of stevedoring are generally considered to be carriers.

    ACT:
    • Subsection 1(1) of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 1 of Part VI of Schedule IX to the ETA
    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Reload centre

    RESULT:

    The services performed in respect of goods at a reload centre are generally considered to be freight transportation services if the property is not further processed, transformed or altered in any way while at the reload centre, other than to the extent that is reasonably necessary to transport the property.
     
    Generally, domestic freight transportation services are taxable at 5%, 13%, or 15% and international freight transportation services are zero-rated.

    DEFINITION:
    A reload centre is used as a cross dock operation where goods are transported to a facility by rail or by truck and then transferred onto another conveyance. The goods are unloaded and, if not immediately reloaded for further transport, are stored for a short period of time (usually 30 days or less).

    ACT:
    • Subsection 1(1) of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 1 of Part VI of Schedule IX to the ETA

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Towing services

    RESULT:

    The service of towing a vehicle is considered to be a freight transportation service.

    Generally, domestic freight transportation services are taxable at 5%, 13%, or 15% and international freight transportation services are zero-rated.

    ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
    Roadside services provided by a tow truck operator such as car boosting, winching, and unlocking doors, by themselves, do not qualify as freight transportation services since they do not involve the transportation of goods. However, if a tow truck operator provides car boosting, or other services prior to towing a vehicle, the car boosting or other services may be part of, or incidental to, the supply of the towing.

    ACT:
    Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule IV to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCES:
    • GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services
    • GST/HST Policy Statement P-077R2, Single and Multiple Supplies
    • GST/HST Policy Statement P-159R1, Meaning of the Phrase “Reasonably Regarded as Incidental”

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Shunting services

    RESULT:

    A shunting service is considered to be a freight transportation service when it is part of or incidental to a freight transportation service.

    DEFINITION:
    The term “shunting” is used by the freight transportation industry to describe the transfer of trailers from a recipient’s yard to a loading dock. Depending on the arrangement, a shunting company may charge, for services that it renders, either the carrier that brought the trailer into the yard or the recipient of the shipment.

    ACT:
    • Subsection 1(1) of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 1 of Part VI of Schedule IX to the ETA

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Sufferance warehouses

    RESULT:

    A sufferance warehouse is not a freight transportation service. However, a supply made by a sufferance warehouse operator licensed under paragraph 24(1)(a) of the Customs Act is zero-rated when the purpose of the service is to enable the examination of the goods before release.

    Services that could be zero-rated include ​​​container handling services such as the physical movement, opening, unpacking, repacking and closing of containers within the confines of a sufferance warehouse to enable examination of the goods before their release.

    The same zero-rating provision does not apply to supplies of office rental space, bay rental fees, or services related to the preparation of entry documents (other than re‑manifesting fees incidental to the handling and storage of goods).
     
    DEFINITION:
    Sufferance warehouses are privately owned and operated facilities licensed by the CBSA and are established for the landing, storage, safekeeping, transfer, examination, delivery and forwarding of imported goods before they are released by the CBSA.

    ACT:
    Section 13 of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Supply by a non-resident

    RESULT:

    A supply of a freight transportation service made in Canada by a non-resident shall be deemed to be made outside Canada (and therefore with no GST/HST collectible on the supply) unless either:
    • the supply is made in the course of a business carried on in Canada; or
    • at the time the supply is made, the person is registered for GST/HST purposes.
    ACT:
    Paragraphs 143(1)(a) and 143(1)(b) of the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Postage and mail delivery

    RESULT:

    The definition of freight transportation service includes the service of delivering mail.

    ACT:
    • Subsection 1(1) of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 1 of Part VI of Schedule IX to the ETA
    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Freight forwarders' services

    RESULT:

    If the freight forwarder assumes liability for the transportation of goods and presents itself as a carrier, the freight forwarder is considered to be a carrier and its service with respect to that transportation is considered to be a freight transportation service that is subject to the same GST/HST rules as a carrier who performs a freight transportation service of actually transporting the goods.

    Generally, domestic freight transportation services are taxable at 5%, 13%, or 15% and international freight transportation services are zero-rated.

    DEFINITION:
    Freight forwarders are generally engaged in assisting shippers with the preparation and booking of a freight transportation service for goods to a destination specified by the shipper or consignee of the property, usually in the context of international trade.

    Freight forwarders may consolidate goods from various shippers for purposes of a freight movement to be transported by the same carrier. For example, a company may hire a freight forwarder to find shippers needing to transport small amounts of cargo to fill a partially-empty conveyance.

    A freight forwarder may be a carrier or may act as an agent on behalf of a shipper or a consignee. It is a question of fact whether a freight forwarder is operating as a carrier, or is arranging for freight transportation services as an agent on behalf of a shipper or a consignee.

    ACT:
    • Subsection 123(1) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Subsection 1(1) of Part VII of Schedule VI to the ETA
    • Section 1 of Part VI of Schedule IX to the ETA

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Settlement paid for loss or damage

    RESULT:

    Although related to a freight transportation service, this does not qualify as a freight transportation service.

    Generally, a settlement in which a carrier compensates a shipper with a payment for goods lost or damaged is not consideration for a supply and is not subject to the GST/HST. 

    ACT:
    Section 182 of the Excise Tax Act (a settlement made by a carrier to the recipient of the supply of freight transportation services for goods lost or damaged in transit does not meet the conditions)

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Policy Statement P218-R, Tax Status of Damage Payments, Whether or Not Within Section 182 of the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Supply to an international carrier

    RESULT:

    Although not considered to be a freight transportation service, a supply of property or a service, such as fuel or maintenance and repair services, to a non-resident carrier who carries on a business of transporting property to or from Canada or between places outside Canada by ship, aircraft or railway and who is not registered for the GST/HST at the time the supply is made, may be zero-rated if the supply is for consumption, use, or supply in the course of so transporting property.

    ACT:
    Section 2 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCES:
    • GST/HST Memorandum 4-5-2, Exports – Tangible Personal Property
    • GST/HST Memorandum 4-5-3, Export - Services and Intellectual Property

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Supplies by agents to non-residents

    RESULT:

    Although not a freight transportation service, a supply of a service of acting as an agent for a non-resident person who is not registered at the time the supply is made is zero-rated, to the extent that the service is in respect of a supply to that person of a freight transportation service that is, or forms part of, a continuous outbound or inbound freight movement.

    ACT:
    Section 12 of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - Rolling stock penalties and demurrage

    RESULT:

    Although related to a freight transportation service, this does not qualify as a freight transportation service.

    An amount that is paid as or on account of demurrage, or any penalties paid by a railway corporation to another railway corporation for delay in returning railway rolling stock are deemed not to be consideration for a supply.

    DEFINITION:
    Demurrage fees are amounts that a shipper pays a carrier for the detention of a ship, freight car, or other cargo conveyance during loading or unloading beyond the scheduled time of departure.

    ACT:
    Section 162.1 of the Excise Tax Act 

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Freight transportation
    4. Is the type of supply a taxable freight transportation service? – Finished - International freight transportation services

    RESULT:

    Outbound international freight transportation services are zero-rated where the goods are valud at $5 or more.

    ACT:
    Sections 6 and 7 of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.2, Freight Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation

    Which option best describes the passenger transportation service?

    • Finished - Ferry
    • Finished - School bus
    • Finished - Tour package
    • Finished - Municipal transit
    • Finished - Domestic ambulance
    • Finished - Taxi or ride-sharing
    • Finished - International air ambulance
    • Finished - Continuous journey including air transportation
    • Finished - Continuous journey not including air transportation
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Ferry

    Is the supply an international ferry transportation service?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Ferry
    5. Is the supply an international ferry transportation service? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated where the principal purpose of ferrying, by watercraft, to or from a place outside Canada is to transport passengers between parts of a road or highway system that are separated by a stretch of water.

    ACT:

    Section 14 of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 28.1, Ferries, Toll Roads and Toll Bridges

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Ferry
    5. Is the supply an international ferry transportation service? – No

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt where the principal purpose of ferrying by watercraft is to transport passengers between parts of a road or highway system that are separated by a stretch of water.

    ACT:

    Section 1 of Part VIII of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 28.1, Ferries, Toll Roads and Toll Bridges

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - School bus

    RESULT:

    A supply made by a school authority to a person (other than to another school authority) of a service of transporting elementary or secondary school students to or from a school that is operated by a school authority is GST/HST exempt.

    ACT:
    Section 5 of Part III of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Tour package

    RESULT:

    If the passenger transportation service is being supplied as part of a tour package, prorate the selling price of the tour package based on the value of the taxable property and services included in the package (using the special rules that must be applied when prorating the selling price of a tour package). Also, before applying the rules the supplier must ensure that what is being supplied is a tour package.

    Generally, taxable supplies are the property and services included in a tour package that, if supplied separately and not as part of a package, would be taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%.

    ACT:
    Section 163 of the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCES:
    • GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services
    • GST/HST Memorandum 27.1, Calculating the GST/HST on Tour Packages

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Municipal transit

    Which option best describes the service?

    • Finished - Municipal transit service (for example, bus, streetcar, subway)
    • Finished - Transit pass/right to use a public passenger transportation service
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Municipal transit
    5. Which option best describes the service? – Finished - Municipal transit service (for example, bus, streetcar, subway)

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt (other than a supply made to a transit authority)

    ACT:
    Section 24 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Municipal transit
    5. Which option best describes the service? – Finished - Transit pass/right to use a public passenger transportation service

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    ACT:
    Section 24.1 of Part VI of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Domestic ambulance

    RESULT:

    A supply of a domestic ambulance service is GST/HST exempt when made by a person who carries on the business of supplying ambulance services.

    ACT:
    Section 4 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Taxi or ride-sharing

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. A provider of commercial ride-sharing services is subject to the same GST/HST rules that apply to taxi operators, including the requirement to register for GST/HST purposes regardless of whether the person is a small supplier, and to collect the GST/HST on those services, because the services are included in the definition of taxi business.

    ACT:
    Section 171.1 of the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCES:
    • GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services
    • GST/HST Info Sheet GI-196, GST/HST and Commercial Ride-sharing Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - International air ambulance

    RESULT:

    A supply of an international air ambulance service is zero-rated where the transportation is to or from a place outside Canada and when it is made by a person who carries on the business of supplying air ambulance services.

    ACT:
    Section 15 of Part II of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Continuous journey including air transportation

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated when provided to an individual or a group of individuals if:
    • the origin or termination of the continuous journey, or any stopover in respect thereof, is outside the taxation area
    • the origin and termination of the continuous journey, and all stopovers in respect thereof, are outside Canada
    • the origin of the continuous journey is within the taxation area, but outside Canada
    • all places at which the individual or group embarks or disembarks an aircraft are outside Canada and the origin or termination of the continuous journey, or any stopover in respect thereof, is outside Canada

    ACT:
    Section 3 of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Transportation services
    3. Which best describes the transportation service? – Passenger transportation
    4. Which option best describes the passenger transportation service? – Finished - Continuous journey not including air transportation

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated when provided to an individual or a group of individuals if:
    • the origin or termination of the continuous journey is outside Canada; or
    • there is a stopover outside Canada.
    Specifically excluded from this zero-rating provision is a passenger transportation service that is part of a continuous journey if both the origin and termination of the journey are in Canada and, at the time the journey begins, the individual or group is not scheduled to be outside Canada for an uninterrupted period of at least 24 hours during the journey. Such continuous journeys (trans-border day trips) are subject to the GST/HST.
    ACT:
    Section 2 of Part VII of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 28.3, Passenger Transportation Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Telecommunication services

    Does the supply meet the definition of telecommunication service for GST/HST purposes?

    For GST/HST purposes, you have to distinguish between a supply that is a supply of a telecommunication service, and the use of telecommunications as a means by which other property and services are supplied.

    DEFINITION:

    For GST/HST purposes, a "telecommunication service" is defined in subsection 123(1) of the Excise Tax Act as:
    1. the service of emitting, transmitting or receiving signs, signals, writing, images or sounds or intelligence of any nature by wire, cable, radio, optical or other electromagnetic system, or by any similar technical system, or
    2. making available for such emission, transmission or reception telecommunications facilities of a person who carries on the business of supplying services referred to in paragraph (a)
    A "telecommunications facility" is defined in subsection 123(1) as:
    any facility, apparatus or other thing (including any wire, cable, radio, optical or other electromagnetic system, or any similar technical system, or any part thereof) that is used or is capable of being used for telecommunications
     
    A supply is generally considered to be a supply of a telecommunication service where its predominant purpose is to:
    • provide for the emission, transmission or reception of signs, signals, etc. (for example, voice or data) through a telecommunications network or similar technical system;
    • make available a telecommunications facility for the emission, transmission or reception of signs, signals, etc. through a telecommunications network or similar technical system; or
    • provide a means through which other services or intangible personal property (for example, content in a digitized format) are delivered, rather than to provide the services or intangible personal property.
    A supply is not generally a supply of a telecommunication service where:
    • a telecommunication service is used or consumed by the supplier in making a supply of a service or property (other than a telecommunication service);
    • it includes the provision of a telecommunication service, but only as a means of delivering another service or property; or
    • it is incidental to the supply of another service or property.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Telecommunication services
    3. Does the supply meet the definition of telecommunication service for GST/HST purposes? – Yes

    Is the supply of a telecommunication service made by a registrant to an unregistered non-resident person in a situation where both carry on the business of supplying telecommunication services?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Telecommunication services
    3. Does the supply meet the definition of telecommunication service for GST/HST purposes? – Yes
    4. Is the supply of a telecommunication service made by a registrant to an unregistered non-resident person in a situation where both carry on the business of supplying telecommunication services? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated export of a telecommunication service, unless the telecommunication is both emitted and received in Canada
     
    ACT:
    Section 22.1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Technical Information Bulletin B-090, GST/HST and Electronic Commerce

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Telecommunication services
    3. Does the supply meet the definition of telecommunication service for GST/HST purposes? – Yes
    4. Is the supply of a telecommunication service made by a registrant to an unregistered non-resident person in a situation where both carry on the business of supplying telecommunication services? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable 5%, 13%, or 15%

    ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
    Although exempting rules apply to supplies by public sector bodies, no zero-rating or exempting provisions apply for most businesses in this situation.

    However, special place of supply rules determine whether the taxable supply is subject to GST at 5% or HST at 13% or 15%. There is also an exception to self-assessment requirements which may apply for the taxable supply of a telecommunication service.

    ACT:
    • Sections 2 and 3 of Part VIII of Schedule IX to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 6 of Part II of Schedule X to the ETA

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Technical Information Bulletin B-090, GST/HST and Electronic Commerce

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Telecommunication services
    3. Does the supply meet the definition of telecommunication service for GST/HST purposes? – No

    RESULT:

    Since the supply does not meet the definition of a telecommunication service for GST/HST purposes, it is not subject to the special place of supply and zero-rating rules for telecommunication services. 

    Generally, every sale, lease or other supply made in Canada is GST/HST taxable at the rate of 5%, 13%, or 15%, based on subsections 165(1) and 165(2) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA), unless it is specifically listed as being:
    • zero-rated under Schedule VI to the ETA
    • GST/HST exempt under Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals

    Which best describes the supply?

    • Finished - Wool
    • Finished - Crops
    • Finished - Farmland
    • Finished - Fertilizer
    • Finished - Pesticides
    • Finished - Live animal
    • Finished - Meat, dairy, fish or eggs
    • Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    • Finished - Sale of fishing equipment
    • Finished - Lease of farming or fishing equipment
    • Updated/now finished - Plants, animal hides or other agricultural goods
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Wool

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if not further processed than washed. Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15% if processed further.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Hay or silage

    Is the quantity of hay being sold more than one large round bale or its equivalent?

    Hay is ordinarily sold in bales of various sizes and shapes. A single large round bale is one that weighs at least 750 kg or 1650 lbs. If the hay were sold in square bales, for example, each weighing 50 kg or 110lbs., the supply would have to be at least 16 bales to be its equivalent quantity.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Hay or silage
    6. Is the quantity of hay being sold more than one large round bale or its equivalent? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Grains or seeds in their natural state, treated for seeding purposes, or irradiated for storage purposes
    6. Is the product being supplied grains, seeds, or grain or seed mixtures that are packaged, prepared or sold for use as feed for wild birds, or as pet food? – No

    Which option best describes the product being supplied?

    What is considered a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers?

    Small seeds

    Small seeds supplied in packages of a quantity exceeding 125 g and large seeds in quantities exceeding five kg are considered a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers.  When small seeds are supplied on a count basis, they are considered a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers when supplied in quantities exceeding 2500 seeds.

    Large seeds

    Large seeds refer to peas, corn and beans only (any other type of seed is considered a small seed). When large seeds are supplied on a count basis, they are considered a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers when supplied in quantities exceeding 20,000 seeds.

    • Lawn seeds or flower seeds
    • Seed potatoes and onion sets
    • Small packets of garden seeds sold to consumers
    • Sold in a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Grains or seeds in their natural state, treated for seeding purposes, or irradiated for storage purposes
    6. Is the product being supplied grains, seeds, or grain or seed mixtures that are packaged, prepared or sold for use as feed for wild birds, or as pet food? – No
    7. Which option best describes the product being supplied? – Lawn seeds or flower seeds

    RESULT:

    GST/HST taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Grains or seeds in their natural state, treated for seeding purposes, or irradiated for storage purposes
    6. Is the product being supplied grains, seeds, or grain or seed mixtures that are packaged, prepared or sold for use as feed for wild birds, or as pet food? – No
    7. Which option best describes the product being supplied? – Seed potatoes and onion sets

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    ACT:

    Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Grains or seeds in their natural state, treated for seeding purposes, or irradiated for storage purposes
    6. Is the product being supplied grains, seeds, or grain or seed mixtures that are packaged, prepared or sold for use as feed for wild birds, or as pet food? – No
    7. Which option best describes the product being supplied? – Small packets of garden seeds sold to consumers
