    GST/HST taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Grains or seeds in their natural state, treated for seeding purposes, or irradiated for storage purposes
    6. Is the product being supplied grains, seeds, or grain or seed mixtures that are packaged, prepared or sold for use as feed for wild birds, or as pet food? – No
    7. Which option best describes the product being supplied? – Sold in a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers

    Are the seeds ordinarily used as, or to produce, food for human consumption or feed for farm livestock or poultry?

    Appendix - Seeds in GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing contains a list of seeds ordinarily used as, or to produce, food for human consumption or feed for farm livestock or poultry. Refer to the Appendix for a list of seeds that the CRA considers to be zero-rated when supplied in a commercial quantity as well as those that are taxable.

    Any seed mixture that is sold or labelled as a forage mixture (for example, Canada Certified No. 1 Forage Mixture) in accordance with Table XIII of Schedule I to the Seeds Regulations made under the Seeds Act is zero-rated when sold in a commercial quantity. Forage mixtures may contain non-zero-rated seeds (for example, creeping red fescue), but as long as they are properly labelled and are supplied in a commercial quantity, supplies of forage mixtures are zero-rated.

    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Crops
    4. Which best describes the crop? – Finished - Grains or seeds (other than hemp), hay or silage, or other fodder crops
    5. Which option best describes the crop being supplied? – Grains or seeds in their natural state, treated for seeding purposes, or irradiated for storage purposes
    6. Is the product being supplied grains, seeds, or grain or seed mixtures that are packaged, prepared or sold for use as feed for wild birds, or as pet food? – No
    7. Which option best describes the product being supplied? – Sold in a quantity larger than that ordinarily sold or offered for sale to consumers

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    REFERENCE:

    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Farmland

    For tax status, see Real property.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Fertilizer

    Is the product sold as soil or as a soil mixture, whether or not containing fertilizer?

    What is considered to be fertilizer?

    A fertilizer is intended to directly provide a plant or crop with nutrients for its growth and crop yield. A supplement that improves the physical condition of soils or aids plant growth or crop yields, thereby indirectly benefiting plant and crop health by aiding in the ability to absorb the nutrients, does not meet this requirement.

    Peat is considered a soil conditioner not a fertilizer, and may be sold as soil or as soil mixture. The supply of peat is taxable regardless of the amount sold.

    A product is considered to be a fertilizer if the following requirements are met:

    • the purpose of the product is to provide plant nutrients;
    • the product contains either
      • one or more of the major plant nutrients; or
      • one or more lesser plant nutrients;
    • the product label contains a “guaranteed analysis” that is verified by a laboratory analysis, and if the product contains major plant nutrients, the “grade” is displayed as part of the product name; and
    • the product being supplied is marketed, advertised, packaged, labelled, or sold for use as a fertilizer.

    Plant nutrients

    The major plant nutrients are nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). The lesser plant nutrients, which must be present in the required minimum levels noted, are as follows:

    Element Minimum per cent (by weight)
    Calcium (Ca) 1.0000
    Magnesium (Mg) 0.5000
    Sulphur (S) 1.0000
    Boron (B) 0.0200
    Chloride (Cl) 0.1000
    Copper (Cu) 0.0500
    Iron (Fe) 0.1000
    Manganese (Mn) 0.0500
    Molybdenum (Mo) 0.0005
    Zinc (Zn) 0.0500

    Note

    All nutrients are expressed by weight. The percent represents the amount of individual plant nutrients in relation to the total product by weight. The exception is for calcium (Ca), magnesium (Mg), and sulphur (S), which are guaranteed as a minimum amount expressed in per cent on an elemental basis.

    Guaranteed analysis

    A guaranteed analysis should be displayed on the label of a fertilizer product. A guaranteed analysis is a legal representation by the supplier of the product guaranteeing the stated percentage of each individual plant nutrient claimed to be in the product, by weight of the total product, for both major and lesser plant nutrients. In the case of supplies in bulk, this guarantee would be displayed on the invoice, on a shipping bill, or on a statement accompanying the supply.

    A guaranteed analysis is to be verified by a laboratory analysis. The principal criterion in determining whether the laboratory analysis is acceptable is that the conclusions be scientifically supported. In this regard, the following are factors to consider when deciding whether or not the conclusions are acceptable:

    • a written report is prepared and signed by an individual employed by the laboratory with the authority to sign and issue such reports;
    • the procedures employed by the laboratory are based on acceptable standards for this type of industry and analysis; and
    • the conclusions are properly documented and supportable.

    A variation between the quantity of individual plant nutrients in a product as stated in the guaranteed analysis and that revealed by a laboratory analysis will not automatically exclude the supply from zero-rating unless the quantities determined to be present by the laboratory analysis are so minimal as to be ineffective.

    Example

    If a product contains only one lesser plant nutrient and the percentage of that lesser plant nutrient is determined to be less than the minimum requirement noted in the above table, then the product would not be zero-rated as it does not meet the requirements of a fertilizer.

    Grade

    Where a fertilizer product contains major plant nutrients, the “grade” is to be displayed as part of the product name. The “grade” is a set of three numbers that represent the minimum guarantee, in order, for the per cent of total N, P, and K in the product, by weight of the total product, in a hyphenated numerical series (N-P-K),
    (for example, 15-10-0).

    Product marketing and sale

    Where a fertilizer product is sold in different packages with one set of packages marketed as a fertilizer and another for some other purpose, only the packages sold for use as a fertilizer will be zero-rated.

    Where a fertilizer product is packaged for sale as both a fertilizer and some other purpose, it will be considered packaged as a fertilizer.

    A fertilizer product that is marketed with no indication as to the product's use is considered to be marketed or sold for use as a fertilizer.

    Fertilizers Act

    Products that are considered to be fertilizers because they meet all of the requirements pursuant to the Fertilizers Act will generally have met all of the criteria noted above and will therefore be considered fertilizers for the purposes of zero-ratings.

    Note

    Animal and vegetable manures in their natural condition are considered to be fertilizers and will be zero-rated when sold in quantities of 500 kg or more, although they may not meet all of the criteria noted above.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Fertilizer
    4. Is the product sold as soil or as a soil mixture, whether or not containing fertilizer? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 5 of Schedule VI of Part IV to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Fertilizer
    4. Is the product sold as soil or as a soil mixture, whether or not containing fertilizer? – No

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated when the fertilizer is supplied in bulk quantities or in containers of at least 25 kg where the total amount of the fertilizer supplied is 500 kg or more

    ACT:

    Section 5 of Schedule VI of Part IV to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses

    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Pesticides

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the item being supplied is a pesticide labelled in accordance with the Pest Control Products Regulations (made under the Pest Control Products Act) as having a purpose that includes agricultural use and a product class designation other than "Domestic".

    ACT:

    Subsection 1(4) of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Live animal

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the supply is of farm livestock (other than rabbits), poultry or bees that are ordinarily raised or kept to produce, or to be used as, food for human consumption, or to produce wool.

    A supply of a rabbit is zero-rated except when the supply is made in the course of a business in which the supplier regularly supplies animals as pets to consumers.

    ACT:

    Sections 1 and 1.1 of Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Meat, dairy, fish or eggs

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if raised or produced as food for people

    ACT:

    Section 1 of Part III of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.3, Basic groceries

    EXAMPLES:

    May be sold fresh, frozen, canned or vacuum sealed

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment

    Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture?

    When zero-rated farm equipment is sold together with any other accessories normally taxable, the supply of such accessories will be zero-rated provided they are attached to the zero-rated farm equipment and form part of the unit. Any accessory sold must already be installed at the time of sale.

    Example

    The sale of a zero-rated tractor together with an air conditioner and a blade attachment is zero-rated provided that the equipment is sold as a complete unit (in other words, the air conditioner and blade attachment were installed on the tractor prior to the sale). The air conditioner and blade attachment are considered to be part of the supply of the tractor.

    When accessories are not sold together with zero-rated equipment, such accessories will not be treated as part of the zero-rated equipment, and will be taxable in the normal manner.

    Example

    An air conditioner installed on a customer-owned tractor would be taxable.

    • Finished - Tractor
    • Finished - Haying equipment
    • Finished - Tillage equipment
    • Finished - Harvesting equipment
    • Finished - Seeders and planters
    • Finished - Grain handling or processing equipment
    • Finished - Other equipment (none of the above)
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Tractor

    Is the tractor designed for farm use with a rating of at least 44.74 kW at power takeoff (60 PTO h.p.)?

    • Yes
    • No

    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Tractor
    5. Is the tractor designed for farm use with a rating of at least 44.74 kW at power takeoff (60 PTO h.p.)? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agricultre and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    5. Is the tractor designed for farm use with a rating of at least 44.74 kW at power takeoff (60 PTO h.p.)? – No

    ACT:

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agricultre and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Haying equipment

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the supply is a sale of any of the following:

    • mower-conditioners
    • hay balers
    • hay cubers
    • bale throwers, elevators or conveyors
    • hay rakes
    • hay tedders
    • hay conditioners, crushers or crimpers
    • swath turners and wind-row turners
    • silage baggers and round bale wrapping machines

    ACT:

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Tillage equipment

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the supply is a sale of any of the following:

    • mouldboard plows with three furrows or more
    • disc plows with three furrows or more
    • chisel plows with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • subsoil chisels with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • discers with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • rod weeders with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • bean rods with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • field cultivators with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • row crop cultivators with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • combination discer-cultivators with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • rototillers with an operational width of at least 1.83 m (6 feet)
    • rotovators with an operational width of at least 1.83 m (6 feet)
    • pulverizers with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • farm-type land packers with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • mulchers with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • rotary hoes with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet)
    • harrows with an operational width of at least 2.44 m (8 feet), when sold in complete units

    Note

    Although sales of harrows in any other sizes are taxable (for example, a dealer selling two separate 4.5 feet sections is required to collect the tax), separate harrow sections are treated as a complete unit when attached together prior to purchase, and are zero-rated provided their total operational width measures at least 2.44 m (8 feet).

    ACT:

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses

    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Harvesting equipment

    • self-propelled or pull-type swathers
    • self-propelled or pull-type wind-rowers
    • headers for combines, forage harvesters, swathers or wind-rowers
    • combine or forage harvester pickups
    • forage harvesters
    • self-propelled, tractor-mounted or pull-type mechanical fruit or vegetable pickers or harvesters

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    ACT:

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Grain handling or processing equipment

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the supply is a sale of any of the following:

    • transportable conveyors with belts less than 76.2 cm (30 inches) wide and 0.48 cm (3/16 inch) thick, transportable farm grain augers, transportable utility augers and transportable elevators
    • bin sweeps or cleaners designed for attachment to portable farm grain augers
    • farm tractor-powered pneumatic grain conveyors
    • farm-type feed mills including roller mills and hammer mills
    • farm-type feed mixers
    • farm-type feed grinder mixers
    • farm-type tub grinders and other farm-type feed grinders
    • ensilage mixers
    • farm-type grain toasters for use in livestock feed production
    • self-propelled feed or ensilage carts
    • grain dryers
    • grain bins or tanks with a capacity of not more than 181 m³ (5,000 bushels)

    Note

    Bulk feed bins and epoxy-coated bins or tanks (or other bins or tanks that are similarly treated or lined to prevent corrosion caused by the storage of fertilizer but are also promoted as suitable for the storage of grains) are zero-rated provided the volume criterion is met.

    ACT:

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of farming equipment
    4. Which option describes the equipment related to agriculture? – Finished - Other equipment (none of the above)

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the supply is a sale of any of the following:

    • farm-type refrigerated bulk milk coolers
    • mechanical rock or stone pickers
    • forage blowers
    • silo unloaders
    • self-propelled, tractor-mounted or pull-type agricultural wagons or trailers designed for
      • off-road handling and transporting of grain, forage, livestock feed, or fertilizer, and
      • use at speeds not exceeding 40 km per hour

    Note

    A supply of running gear, a component of agricultural wagons or trailers, is taxable when sold separately.

    • shredders with an operational width of at least 3.66 m (12 feet)
    • assembled, fully operational milking systems consisting of a receiver group, vacuum supplier, pulsators and related equipment
    • individual components of a milking system that consists of a receiver group, vacuum supplier, pulsators and related equipment, when the components are supplied together unassembled and, once assembled, constitute the fully operational milking system
    • assembled and fully operational automated and computerized farm livestock or poultry feeding systems
    • individual components of an automated and computerized farm livestock or poultry feeding system, when the components are supplied together unassembled and, once assembled, constitute the fully operational system
    • rock or root rakes and rock or root wind-rowers
    • self-propelled, tractor-mounted, cultivator-mounted or pull-type field sprayers with a total tank capacity of at least 300 L (66 gallons)

    Note

    The supply of a complete field sprayer kit, including the spray tank, is zero-rated. The supply of an incomplete field sprayer kit (for example, without a spray tank) or a supply of the components of a field sprayer is taxable.

    • farm-type granular fertilizer or pesticide applicators with an operational capacity of at least 0.2265 m³ (8 cubic feet)
    • liquid, box, tank or flail manure spreaders
    • injection systems for liquid manure spreaders
    • leafcutter bees

    ACT:

    Section 1 of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of fishing equipment

    Which option describes the fishing equipment?

    When zero-rated fishing equipment is sold together with any other accessories normally taxable, the supply of such accessories will be zero-rated provided they are attached to the zero-rated fishing equipment and form part of the unit. Any accessory sold must already be installed at the time of sale.

    When accessories are not sold together with zero-rated equipment, such accessories will not be treated as part of the zero-rated equipment, and will be taxable in the normal manner.

    • Fishing vessels
    • Fishing nets and related items
    • Other fishing equipment (none of the above)
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of fishing equipment
    4. Which option describes the fishing equipment? – Fishing vessels

    RESULT:

    If acquired for recreational use, the sale of a fishing vessel is taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%.

    If acquired for use in commercial fishing, the sale of a fishing vessel in Canada is zero-rated where the following is provided to the supplier at the time of the sale. Also, the sale of a fishing vehicle outside Canada that is imported by the person for their use in commercial fishing is zero-rated where the following is provided to the Canada Customs office from which the vessel is released at the time of accounting for the vessel in accordance with section 32 of the Customs Act:

    1. their GST/HST registration number
    2. a declaration signed by the person that the person intends to use the vessel in commercial fishing
    3. the number of the person's commercial fishing licence and/or registration card issued by the Department of Fisheries and Oceans or a provincial government

    ACT:

    Subsection 2(1) of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Sale of fishing equipment
    4. Which option describes the fishing equipment? – Fishing nets and related items

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated if the supply is a sale of any of the following:

    • gill-nets, webbing for gill-nets, leadline for gill-nets, corkline (top rope) for gill-nets and floats for gill-nets
    • seines, webbing for seines, leadlines for seines, corkline (top rope) for seines and floats for seines
    • trawl-nets, webbing for trawl-nets, leadlines for trawl-nets and corkline (top rope) for trawl-nets (Note: The supply of floats for trawl nets is taxable.)
    • gill-net drums, seine drums, trawl-net drums and long-line drums
    • entrapment webbing and predator webbing
    • trawl-net doors

    ACT:

    Subsection 2(3) of the Schedule to the Agriculture and Fishing Property (GST/HST) Regulations

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Lease of farming or fishing equipment

    RESULT:

    A supply of prescribed property listed in the Regulations other than by way of sale is at 5%, 13% or 15%. 

    However, when a lease of zero-rated equipment is entered into with an option to purchase the equipment at the end of the lease period, the buy-out portion may be zero-rated if, according to the terms of the agreement, the buy-out constitutes a supply by way of sale. The lease payments made prior to the buy-out payment will be taxable.

    ACT:

    Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply of farming equipment other than by way of sale.

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.4, Agriculture and fishing

    ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

    The supply of prescribed property under a lease-to-own contract may be zero-rated if there is in substance a supply by way of sale. Such contracts must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Agriculture, fishing or animals
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Updated/now finished - Plants, animal hides or other agricultural goods

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Part IV of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does zero-rate cut flowers, bedding plants, sod, trees, firewood, fur and animal hides, feathers or down.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs

    Which best describes the supply?

    • Finished - Medical and assistive devices
    • Finished - Biologicals for reproductive services
    • Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    • Finished - Modification of a motor vehicle for individual using a wheelchair
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Medical and assistive devices

    RESULT:

    A supply of any of the following medical any assistive devices is zero-rated:

    • aids to locomotion
    • articles for blind individuals
    • artificial eye
    • artificial limb
    • artificial teeth
    • asthmatic devices
    • auxiliary driving control
    • blood-glucose monitor or meter
    • breathing apparatus
    • canes or crutches
    • catheters
    • colostomy appliance
    • commode chairs
    • communication device
    • compressors, respiratory monitors etc
    • dialysis machines
    • eyeglasses/contact lenses
    • feeding utensils
    • footwear appliances
    • gastro-intestinal tubes
    • guide dogs for blind individuals
    • hearing aid
    • hearing ear dogs
    • heart-monitoring device
    • hospital beds
    • ileostomy appliance
    • incontinence products
    • insulin infusion pump or syringe
    • intravenous apparatus
    • lancets
    • laryngeal speaking aid
    • lymphedema devices
    • mechanical percussor
    • modifying motor vehicles
    • nebulizers
    • orthodontic appliances
    • orthotic and orthopaedic devices
    • patient lifter
    • patterning device
    • portable wheelchair ramp
    • prone boards
    • prosthesis
    • reaching aids
    • selector device
    • sound/light conversion device
    • specially designed clothing
    • specially designed footwear
    • stockings
    • testing strips
    • toilet-, bath- or shower-seat
    • tracheostomy supplies
    • urinary appliance
    • wheelchairs
    • wheelchair ramp
    • walkers

    In addition, the supply of a service related to zero-rated medical and assistive devices is generally zero-rated. However, there are exceptions (zero-rating does not apply if the service is either exempt or is related to the provision of a surgical or dental service that is performed for cosmetic purposes and not for medical or reconstructive purposes).

    ACT:

    Sections 1 through 41 of Part 2 of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.2 - Medical and assistive devices

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Biologicals for reproductive services

    RESULT:

    A supply of human sperm is zero-rated. A supply of an ovum, as defined in section 3 of the Assisted Human Reproduction Act, whether mature or not, is zero-rated.

    ACT:

    Section 5 of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act.
    Section 6 of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act.

    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription

    Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply 

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.1 - Drugs and biologicals

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No

    Is the drug listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act?

    The following are drugs or substances listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act:

    • a drug included in Schedule C or D to the Food and Drugs Act
    • a drug that is set out on the list established under subsection 29.1(1) of the Food and Drugs Act or that belongs to a class of drugs set out on that list, other than a drug or mixture of drugs that may, under that Act or the Food and Drug Regulations, be sold to a consumer without a prescription
    • a drug or other substance included in the schedule to Part G of the Food and Drug Regulations
    • a drug that contains a substance included in the schedule to the Narcotic Control Regulations, other than a drug or mixture of drugs that may, pursuant to the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act or regulations made under that Act, be sold to a consumer with neither a prescription nor an exemption by the Minister of Health in respect of the sale
    • a drug included in Schedule 1 to the Benzodiazepines and Other Targeted Substances Regulations
    • any of the following drugs:
      • Digoxin
      • Digitoxin
      • Prenylamine
      • Deslanoside
      • Erythrityl tetranitrate
      • Isosorbide dinitrate
      • Isosorbide-5-mononitrate
      • Nitroglycerine
      • Quinidine and its salts
      • Medical oxygen
      • Epinephrine and its salts
      • Naloxone and its salts
    • a drug the supply of which is authorized under the Food and Drug Regulations for use in an emergency treatment
    • plasma expander

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No
    5. Is the drug listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – Yes

    RESULT:

    The supply is zero-rated throughout the production and distribution chain (regardless of who sells them).

    ACT:

    Section 2 of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act 

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.1 - Drugs and biologicals

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No
    5. Is the drug listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No

    Is the drug being supplied over-the-counter at a pharmacy?

    An over-the-counter drug is physically controlled by a pharmacist. Consumers have to ask a pharmacist for an over-the-counter drug as opposed to products that a consumer can take directly off the shelf for purchase.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No
    5. Is the drug listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
    6. Is the drug being supplied over-the-counter at a pharmacy? – Yes

    Is the over-the-counter drug being supplied under the prescription of a medical practitioner?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No
    5. Is the drug listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
    6. Is the drug being supplied over-the-counter at a pharmacy? – Yes
    7. Is the over-the-counter drug being supplied under the prescription of a medical practitioner? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    ACT:

    Section 3 of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.1 - Drugs and biologicals

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No

    6. Is the drug being supplied over-the-counter at a pharmacy? – Yes
    7. Is the over-the-counter drug being supplied under the prescription of a medical practitioner? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply 

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.1 - Drugs and biologicals

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Drugs, with or without a prescription
    4. Is the drug labelled or supplied for agricultural or veterinary use only? – No
    5. Is the drug listed in paragraphs 2(a) through (f) of Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act? – No
    6. Is the drug being supplied over-the-counter at a pharmacy? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. This includes the supply of a non-prescription drug that is available off the shelf in pharmacies, grocery stores and other retail outlets. It also includes the supply of a product intended for the treatment of a minor ailment that is not considered to be a drug (for example, medicated shampoos and cough drops which can be purchased in a variety of retail outlets).

    ACT:

    Part I of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act does not zero-rate the supply 

    REFERENCE:

    GST/HST Memorandum 4.1 - Drugs and biologicals

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Medical devices or prescription drugs
    3. Which best describes the supply? – Finished - Modification of a motor vehicle for individual using a wheelchair

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated for a supply of a service of modifying a motor vehicle to adapt the vehicle for the transportation of an individual using a wheelchair.

    Zero-rated for a supply of property (other than the vehicle) made in conjunction with, and because of, the supply of that modification service.

    Also zero-rated for a supply of an auxiliary driving control that is designed for attachment to a motor vehicle to facilitate the operation of the vehicle by an individual with a physical disability.

    ACT:

    Sections 18 and 18.1 of Part II of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    Paragraph 1(e) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    2. What is being supplied? – Admission to sports or entertainment event
    3. For this event, is it the case that at least 90% of the performers, athletes or competitors that are taking part do not receive, directly or indirectly, remuneration for doing so (other than a reasonable amount as prizes, gifts or compensation for travel or other expenses incidental to their participation in the event, or grants paid by a government or a municipality to the performers, athletes or competitors)? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:

    Neither section 11 of Part VI or section 1 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act exempts the supply in this situation (Note: the rules for exemption in section 11 are not restricted to public sector bodies; admissions to amateur performances sponsored by other entities, even for-profit entities or charities, also qualify)

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Most businesses
    2. What is being supplied? – Home care service rendered to an individual in their home

    RESULT:
    Home care service means a household or personal care service, such as bathing, feeding, assistance with dressing or medication, cleaning, laundering, meal preparation and child care, if the service is rendered to an individual who, due to age, infirmity or disability, requires assistance.
    A home care service is GST/HST exempt if one of the 3 following conditions are met:

    1. the supplier is a government or municipality
    2. a government, municipality or organization administering a government or municipal program in respect of home care services pays an amount to either:
    • the supplier in respect of the supply
    • any person for the purpose of the acquisition of the service; or
    1. another supply of a home care service rendered to the individual is made in the circumstances described in #1 or #2 above (for example, where funding by the government or the municipality is insufficient to cover the entire cost of the home care services needed by the individual and the individuals must pay the additional costs instead)
    ACT:
    Section 13 of Part II of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act
    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memoradum 21.3 - Respite Care Services

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services

    What is the financial service that is being supplied?

    • A supply that is deemed to be a financial service
    • Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    • Any other financial service in Canada
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – A supply that is deemed to be a financial service

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt
     
    ACT:
    1. Subsection 150(1) of the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Section 2 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution

    Does the service relate to a debt?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – Yes

    What is the debt for?

    • Real property that is situated in Canada
    • Lending of money that is primarily for use in Canada
    • A service that is to be performed primarily in Canada
    • Personal property that is for use primarily in Canada
    • Deposit of funds in Canada, where the instrument issued as evidence of the deposit is a negotiable instrument
    • None of the above
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – Yes
    4. What is the debt for? – Real property that is situated in Canada

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    2. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    4. What is the debt for? – A service that is to be performed primarily in Canada

    • No

    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – No
    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No

    Does the service relate to an insurance policy issued by the financial institution (other than a service that relates to investments made by the institution)?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – No
    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No
    5. Does the service relate to an insurance policy issued by the financial institution (other than a service that relates to investments made by the institution)? – Yes

    Which of the following describes the insurance policy?

    • In respect of real property
    • Group life or accident and sickness insurance policy
    • Life or accident and sickness insurance policy (other than a group policy)
    • None of the above
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – No
    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No
    5. Does the service relate to an insurance policy issued by the financial institution (other than a service that relates to investments made by the institution)? – Yes
    6. Which of the following describes the insurance policy? – In respect of real property

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated to the extent that it relates to property situated outside Canada. Otherwise, GST/HST exempt.
     
    ACT:
    1. Paragraph 2(c) of Part IX of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – No
    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No
    5. Does the service relate to an insurance policy issued by the financial institution (other than a service that relates to investments made by the institution)? – Yes
    6. Which of the following describes the insurance policy? – Group life or accident and sickness insurance policy

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated to the extent that it relates to non-resident individuals who are insured under the policy. Otherwise, GST/HST exempt.
     
    ACT:
    1. Paragraph 2(b) of Part IX of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – No
    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No
    5. Does the service relate to an insurance policy issued by the financial institution (other than a service that relates to investments made by the institution)? – Yes
    6. Which of the following describes the insurance policy? – Life or accident and sickness insurance policy (other than a group policy)

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated to the extent that it is issued in respect of an individual who at the time the policy becomes effective, is a non-resident individual. Otherwise, GST/HST exempt.
     
    ACT:
    1. Paragraph 2(a) of Part IX of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services
    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Supply made to a non-resident by a financial institution
    3. Does the service relate to a debt? – No
    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No
    5. Does the service relate to an insurance policy issued by the financial institution (other than a service that relates to investments made by the institution)? – Yes
    6. Which of the following describes the insurance policy? – None of the above

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated to the extent that it relates to risks that are ordinarily situated outside Canada. Otherwise, GST/HST exempt.
     
    ACT:
    1. Paragraph 2(d) of Part IX of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Financial services

    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No

    Is the financial service the supply of precious metals where the supply is made by the refiner thereof or by the person on whose behalf the precious metals were refined?

    • No

    4. Does the service relate to a financial instrument (other than an insurance policy or a precious metal) acquired, otherwise than directly from a non-resident issuer, by the financial institution acting as a principal? – No

    2. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the ETA

    2. What is the financial service that is being supplied? – Any other financial service in Canada

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt
     
    ACT:
    1. Section 1 of Part VII of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Subsection 123(1) of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting

    How is the supply being made?

    See GST/HST – Imports and Exports for additional information relating to this topic

    • Imports
    • Exports
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports

    Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites?

    • Yes (importing for commercial use)
    • No (importing for personal use)
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)

    What is the imported supply?

    • Tangible personal property (goods)
    • Services
    • Intangible personal property
    • Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Tangible personal property (goods)

    Are the goods included in Schedule VII, Non-Taxable Importations, to the Excise Tax Act?

    Schedule VII contains a complete list of goods that are not GST/HST-taxable when imported.

    However, if the goods are taxable when imported and the recipient of the goods is a GST/HST registrant, the importer of record of the goods, and the goods are delivered or made available to purchasers in Canada, the following steps generally apply:

    1. The recipient pays the GST or the federal part of the HST at the time of importation.
    2. The recipient can claim an input tax credit (ITC) for the GST or the federal part of the HST paid or payable if the imported goods are for consumption, use or supply in their commercial activity.
    3. The recipient charges the GST/HST to their customers on the sale price.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    5. Are the goods included in Schedule VII, Non-Taxable Importations, to the Excise Tax Act? – Yes

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is required.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    2. Section 218 of the ETA
    3. Schedule VII to the ETA - contains a complete list of goods that are not GST/HST-taxable when imported

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    5. Are the goods included in Schedule VII, Non-Taxable Importations, to the Excise Tax Act? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the person who is liable (or would be liable) under the Customs Act to pay duty on imported goods must pay GST, or the federal part of the HST, on the goods calculated on the value of the goods. The provincial component of the HST does not apply to imported goods that are accounted for as commercial goods

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA
    3. Subsection 212.1(3) of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Services

    Is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Services
    5. Is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Yes

    RESULT:

    GST/HST will apply to the supply of the service unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason. The GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Services
    5. Is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – No

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is required because the exclusive commercial use of the service excludes the supply from the definition of an "imported taxable supply". The self-assessment rules therefore do not apply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting

    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Intangible personal property

    Is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Intangible personal property
    5. Is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Yes

    RESULT:

    GST/HST will apply to the supply of IPP unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason. The GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Intangible personal property
    5. Is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – No

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is required because the exclusive commercial use of the IPP excludes the supply from the definition of an "imported taxable supply". The self-assessment rules therefore do not apply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)

    Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST?

    The draft proposed legislation creates a new simplified regime, instead of requiring certain non-residents to register under the existing GST/HST regime. The rules are not the same. For example, the non-resident will only be required to collect GST/HST on business-to-consumer sales of digital products and services. For these purposes, a person that is registered for the GST/HST and provides its GST/HST registration number to the registrant will be considered a business, and any other entity or person will be considered a consumer.

    REFERENCE:

    Subdivision E of Division II of the Excise Tax Act

    • Regular GST/HST registration
    • Simplified GST/HST registration
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)
    5. Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Regular GST/HST registration

    RESULT:

    GST/HST will apply unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason. The GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)
    5. Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Simplified GST/HST registration

    Is the recipient of the imported supply a GST/HST registrant that provided their GST/HST account number to the non-resident supplier?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – Yes (importing for commercial use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)
    5. Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Simplified GST/HST registration
    6. Is the recipient of the imported supply a GST/HST registrant that provided their GST/HST account number to the non-resident supplier? – Yes

    No GST/HST to be paid to non-resident supplier in this case. Add details relating to whether self-assessment is required, etc

    Are the goods included in Schedule VII, Non-Taxable Importations, to the Excise Tax Act?

    Schedule VII contains a complete list of goods that are not GST/HST-taxable when imported.

    However, if the goods are taxable when imported and the recipient of the goods is a GST/HST registrant, the importer of record of the goods, and the goods are delivered or made available to purchasers in Canada, the following steps generally apply:

    1. The recipient pays the GST or the federal part of the HST at the time of importation.
    2. The recipient can claim an input tax credit (ITC) for the GST or the federal part of the HST paid or payable if the imported goods are for consumption, use or supply in their commercial activity.
    3. The recipient charges the GST/HST to their customers on the sale price.

    4. What is the imported supply? – Tangible personal property (goods)

    RESULT:

    Taxable. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the person who is liable (or would be liable) under the Customs Act to pay duty on imported goods must pay GST/HST calculated on the value of the goods.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA
    3. Subsection 212.1(3) of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – No (importing for personal use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Services

    RESULT:

    GST, or the federal part of the HST, must be self-assessed by the recipient of the imported service. For example, a recipient would report the tax on line 405 of their GST/HST return and remit the tax directly to us.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – No (importing for personal use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Intangible personal property

    RESULT:

    GST, or the federal part of the HST, must be self-assessed by the recipient of the imported IPP. For example, a recipient would report the tax on line 405 of their GST/HST return and remit the tax directly to us.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – No (importing for personal use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)

    Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST?

    The draft proposed legislation creates a new simplified regime, instead of requiring certain non-residents to register under the existing GST/HST regime. The rules are not the same. For example, the non-resident will only be required to collect GST/HST on business-to-consumer sales of digital products and services. For these purposes, a person that is registered for the GST/HST and provides its GST/HST registration number to the registrant will be considered a business, and any other entity or person will be considered a consumer.

    REFERENCE:

    Subdivision E of Division II of the Excise Tax Act

    • Regular GST/HST registration
    • Simplified GST/HST registration
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – No (importing for personal use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)
    5. Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Regular GST/HST registration

    RESULT:

    GST/HST will apply unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason. The GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports

    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)

    • No
