    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Imports
    3. Is the recipient importing for use 90% or more in their commercial activites? – No (importing for personal use)
    4. What is the imported supply? – Supplies by a non-resident in the digital economy (July 2021 changes)
    5. Under which regime is the non-resident supplier registered for the GST/HST? – Simplified GST/HST registration
    6. Is the recipient of the imported supply a GST/HST registrant that provided their GST/HST account number to the non-resident supplier? – No

    RESULT:

    GST/HST will apply unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason. The GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    1. Section 217 of the Excise Tax Act (ETA) - definition of "imported taxable supply"
    2. Section 218 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports

    What is being exported?

    • Tangible personal property (goods)
    • Services
    • Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)

    How are the goods being exported?

    The following rules do not apply for a continuous transmission commodity that is being transported by means of a wire, pipeline, or other conduit.

    • The supplier is exporting the goods
    • The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    • The Canadian supplier is selling goods to a non-registrant that is not registered for the GST/HST but is transferring their physical possession to another person in Canada on behalf of the non-resident
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The supplier is exporting the goods

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is charged for the supply because this type of supply is considered to be made outside Canada.

    REFERENCE:

    Subsection 142(2) of the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLES:

    1. The supplier sends the goods by mail or courier to an address outside Canada.
    2. The supplier ships the goods to a destination outside Canada that is specified in the contract for carriage of the goods.
    3. The supplier transfers possession of the goods to a common carrier or consignee that:
      • is retained to ship the property to a destination outside Canada
      • is retained either by the supplier on the recipient’s behalf or by the recipient’s employer

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods

    Is the recipient a consumer?

    A consumer is usually an individual who is buying the goods for their personal use.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – Yes

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No

    Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – Yes

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No

    After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – Yes

    Was the further processing, transforming, or altering of the goods in Canada reasonably necessary or incidental to transport them?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – Yes
    8. Was the further processing, transforming, or altering of the goods in Canada reasonably necessary or incidental to transport them? – Yes

    Was the supplier provided with evidence satisfactory to the Minister of National Revenue of exportation of the property by the recipient?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – Yes
    8. Was the further processing, transforming, or altering of the goods in Canada reasonably necessary or incidental to transport them? – Yes
    9. Was the supplier provided with evidence satisfactory to the Minister of National Revenue of exportation of the property by the recipient? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated. The supplier must maintain the evidence of exportation of the goods by the recipient.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – Yes
    8. Was the further processing, transforming, or altering of the goods in Canada reasonably necessary or incidental to transport them? – Yes
    9. Was the supplier provided with evidence satisfactory to the Minister of National Revenue of exportation of the property by the recipient? – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – Yes
    8. Was the further processing, transforming, or altering of the goods in Canada reasonably necessary or incidental to transport them? – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – No

    Was the supplier provided with evidence satisfactory to the Minister of National Revenue of exportation of the property by the recipient?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – No
    8. Was the supplier provided with evidence satisfactory to the Minister of National Revenue of exportation of the property by the recipient? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated. The supplier must maintain the evidence of exportation of the goods by the recipient.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The recipient is responsible for exporting the goods
    5. Is the recipient a consumer? – No
    6. Did the recipient buy the goods to consume, use, or supply in Canada before exporting them? – No
    7. After buying the goods and before exporting them, did the recipient further process, transform, or alter the goods in Canada? – No
    8. Was the supplier provided with evidence satisfactory to the Minister of National Revenue of exportation of the property by the recipient? – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Tangible personal property (goods)
    4. How are the goods being exported? – The Canadian supplier is selling goods to a non-registrant that is not registered for the GST/HST but is transferring their physical possession to another person in Canada on behalf of the non-resident

    RESULT:

    Drop shipment certificate option may be available to deem the supplier to have made a supply of the goods to the non-resident recipient for consideration equal to their fair market value. No GST/HST would then be charged for the supply because this type of supply would be considered to be made outside Canada.

    REFERENCES:

    1. Section 179 of the Excise Tax Act
    2. GST/HST Memorandum 3.3.1, Drop Shipments

     

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services

    Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident?

    • Postal service
    • Advertising services
    • Air navigation services
    • Telecommunication service
    • Service under warranty of non-resident
    • Emergency repairs to railway rolling stock
    • Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    • The service is performed entirely outside Canada
    • Testing or inspecting tangible personal property
    • Emergency repairs to conveyances or cargo containers
    • Instructing individuals or administering examinations
    • The service is performed on temporarily imported goods
    • Acting as an agent or representative for a non-resident person
    • Destroying or discarding tangible personal property in Canada
    • Dismantling property for the purpose of exporting the property
    • Custodial or nominee services in respect of securities or precious metals
    • Any other service rendered to an individual while that individual is in Canada
    • None of the above
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Postal service

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the supplier carries on the business of providing postal services and the recipient is not registered for the GST/HST.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 22 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advertising services

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the non-resident is not registered for the GST/HST at the time of the service.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 8 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Air navigation services

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the service is:

    • supplied to a non-registrant that is registered for the GST/HST,
    • the supplier carries on a business of transporting passengers or property to or from Canada, or between places outside Canada, by aircraft, and
    • the service is acquired by the non-resident for use in the course of so transporting passengers or property.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 2.2 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Telecommunication service

    Is the telecommunication service both emitted and received in Canada?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Telecommunication service
    5. Is the telecommunication service both emitted and received in Canada? – Yes

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 22.1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A non-resident is on holiday in Canada. She places a long distance call from Cambridge, Ontario, to Kelowna, British Columbia, and pays for the call with her calling card issued by a non-resident telephone company (NRTelco). As the telephone call was emitted and received in Canada, the supply cannot be zero-rated. Therefore, when the Canadian telephone company bills NRTelco for the call, the Canadian company will charge GST/HST on the amount of the bill.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Telecommunication service
    5. Is the telecommunication service both emitted and received in Canada? – No

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the supplier carries on a business of supplying such services to a non-resident who is not a GST/HST registrant and who also carries on a business of supplying a telecommunication service.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 22.1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Service under warranty of non-resident

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the non-resident is not registered for the GST/HST. Supplies of tangible personal property (for example, parts) supplied in conjunction with such services are also zero-rated.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 13 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A Canadian subsidiary charges its non-resident parent company, which is not registered for the GST/HST, for the service of repairing cars pursuant to a warranty provided by the parent company. The charge for the service is zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Emergency repairs to railway rolling stock

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the non-resident is not registered for the GST/HST and the railway rolling stock is being used in the course of a business to transport passengers or property.

    Supplies of tangible personal property (for example, parts) supplied in conjunction with such services are also zero-rated.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 6.1 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    While transporting an empty tank car from Montreal to Quebec City, the domestic carrier notices that one of the wheels of the tank car is damaged. The carrier delivers the empty tank car to a repair facility. The repair firm contacts the non-resident lessor of the tank car and obtains authorization to repair the tank car. The non-resident lessor is not registered for the GST/HST. Following the repairs, the tank car is returned to the carrier for transportation to Quebec City. The repair service, including the parts, supplied by the repair firm to the non-resident is zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services

    Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the service is intended to help the non-resident either become a resident of Canada or establish a business venture in Canada.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 9 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A Canadian company supplies legal services to non-residents advising them of the various laws and regulations with which they must comply to obtain Canadian residency. Supplies of those legal services are zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No

    Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident?

    • Service in respect of real property property situated in Canada
    • Litigation services in connection with criminal, civil or administrative litigation in Canada
    • Service in respect of tangible personal property situated in Canada at the time of the service
    • None of the above
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No
    6. Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident? – Service in respect of real property property situated in Canada

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 23(b) of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No
    6. Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident? – Litigation services in connection with criminal, civil or administrative litigation in Canada

    Are the services being rendered before the commencement of such litigation?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No
    6. Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident? – Litigation services in connection with criminal, civil or administrative litigation in Canada
    7. Are the services being rendered before the commencement of such litigation? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 23(a) of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No
    6. Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident? – Litigation services in connection with criminal, civil or administrative litigation in Canada
    7. Are the services being rendered before the commencement of such litigation? – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 23(a) of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No
    6. Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident? – Service in respect of tangible personal property situated in Canada at the time of the service

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 23(c) of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Advisory, consulting, or professional services
    5. Is the supply an advisory, consulting or research service being made to a person moving to, or establishing a business, in Canada? – No
    6. Which type of advisory, consulting or professional service is being provided to the non-resident? – None of the above

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    REFERENCE:

    Section 23 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – The service is performed entirely outside Canada

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is charged for the supply of the service because this type of supply is considered to be made outside Canada.

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 142(2)(g) of the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Testing or inspecting tangible personal property

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the non-resident is not registered for the GST/HST and the tangible personal property that is being tested or inspected is acquired or imported for the sole purpose of having the service performed and that it is to be destroyed or discarded in the course of providing the service or upon completion of the service

    REFERENCE:

    Section 21 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Emergency repairs to conveyances or cargo containers

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the conveyances or cargo containers are being used or transported in the course of a business of transporting passengers or property by the person the emergency service is being supplied to.

    Supplies of tangible personal property (for example, parts) supplied in conjunction with such services are also zero-rated.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 6 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A domestic carrier is responsible for repairing damaged cargo containers or conveyances that belong to other carriers while the containers or conveyances are in the domestic carrier's possession. The supply of the repair service (and related parts) is zero-rated because a non-resident is the recipient of the service.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Instructing individuals or administering examinations

    Was the supply made to a school authority or other non-resident (other than an individual) that is not registered for the GST/HST?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Instructing individuals or administering examinations
    5. Was the supply made to a school authority or other non-resident (other than an individual) that is not registered for the GST/HST? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the service of instructing non-resident individuals in, or administering examinations, is:

    • for courses leading to certificates, diplomas, licences or similar documents
    • for classes or ratings in respect of licences that attest to the competence of the individuals to whom the service is rendered
    • administered to practise or perform a trade or vocation

    REFERENCE:

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A supply made by a vocational school to a non-resident corporation that is not registered of a service of instructing the corporation's employees in flight-training may be zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Instructing individuals or administering examinations
    5. Was the supply made to a school authority or other non-resident (other than an individual) that is not registered for the GST/HST? – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 18 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – The service is performed on temporarily imported goods

    Is the supply a transportation service?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – The service is performed on temporarily imported goods
    5. Is the supply a transportation service? – Yes

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 4 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – The service is performed on temporarily imported goods
    5. Is the supply a transportation service? – No

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated. A supply of a service (other than a transportation service) in respect of tangible personal property that is ordinarily situated outside Canada and that is temporarily imported into Canada for the sole purpose of having the service performed is zero-rated. 

    The tangible personal property must be exported as soon as is practicable after the service is performed to qualify for this tax relief.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 4 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:

    Supplies of tangible personal property (for example, parts) supplied in conjunction with such services are also zero-rated.

    EXAMPLE:

    A Canadian company supplies maintenance and repair services for trailers owned by U.S. clients. The trailers are imported for the purpose of maintenance and repair, and exported once these services have been performed. When invoicing its non-resident clients, the Canadian company provides a breakdown of the costs -- one total for parts, and another total for labour. Because the Canadian company is making a supply of both parts and labour, both supplies will be zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Acting as an agent or representative for a non-resident person

    Is that service in respect of a supply to the non-resident that is either made outside Canada or zero-rated as an export? 

    For information on what constitutes an agency relationship, see Policy Statement P-182, Determining the Meaning of "Agent" and "Agency".

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Acting as an agent or representative for a non-resident person
    5. Is that service in respect of a supply to the non-resident that is either made outside Canada or zero-rated as an export?  – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated 

    REFERENCE:

    Section 5 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    An non-resident corporation (USCo) is located in the United States and is not registered for the GST/HST. They enter into a contract with a Canadian sales representative to promote USCo's products in the specific geographic area of Manitoba. The solicitation is done by mail, telephone, door-to-door and through participation in trade shows where the products are demonstrated and free samples are given. The sales representative may also help customers complete purchase orders. However, purchase orders are accepted by USCo outside Canada. The sales representative is paid a commission for her services, based on 5% of the value of the sales of USCo's products in Manitoba. The supply of the service provided by the sales representative is zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Acting as an agent or representative for a non-resident person
    5. Is that service in respect of a supply to the non-resident that is either made outside Canada or zero-rated as an export?  – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of a service. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 5 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Destroying or discarding tangible personal property in Canada

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the non-resident is not registered for the GST/HST.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 19 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Dismantling property for the purpose of exporting the property

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated, provided the non-resident is not registered for the GST/HST.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 20 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A trust operating in Europe leased plant equipment and machinery to a Canadian company that went into receivership. To facilitate the repossession of the equipment and machinery, the trust contracted with a Canadian company to arrange to have the leased equipment and machinery dismantled, crated, transported, stored, and finally exported. The supply of the service of dismantling this property is zero-rated, provided the trust is a non-resident person that is not registered for the GST/HST.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Custodial or nominee services in respect of securities or precious metals

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    REFERENCE:

    Section 17 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A Canadian financial institution supplies corporate trust services to a non-resident person. This service includes maintaining a register of Canadian share/bond holders, printing and disbursing of dividend/interest cheques, and communicating with share/bond holders. The services provided by the financial institution include the safekeeping of the non-resident client's securities and the duties that relate to the custody of the securities. The service, therefore, qualifies for zero-rating.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – Any other service rendered to an individual while that individual is in Canada

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    REFERENCE:

    Section 7 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Services
    4. Which of the following best describes the service being supplied to the non-resident? – None of the above

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated

    REFERENCE:

    Section 7 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)

    Can the IPP be used in Canada?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    4. Can the IPP be used in Canada? – Yes

    Does the IPP relate to real property situated outside Canada, to tangible personal property ordinarily situated outside Canada or to a service to be performed wholly outside Canada?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    4. Can the IPP be used in Canada? – Yes
    5. Does the IPP relate to real property situated outside Canada, to tangible personal property ordinarily situated outside Canada or to a service to be performed wholly outside Canada? – Yes

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is charged for the supply because this type of supply is considered to be made outside Canada.

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 142(2)(c) of the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    4. Can the IPP be used in Canada? – Yes
    5. Does the IPP relate to real property situated outside Canada, to tangible personal property ordinarily situated outside Canada or to a service to be performed wholly outside Canada? – No

    Is the IPP intellectual property being supplied to a non-resident that is not registered for the GST/HST?

    Intellectual property includes an invention, patent, trade secret, trade-mark, trade-name, copyright, industrial design or other intellectual property, or any right, licence or privilege to use any such intellectual property.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    4. Can the IPP be used in Canada? – Yes
    5. Does the IPP relate to real property situated outside Canada, to tangible personal property ordinarily situated outside Canada or to a service to be performed wholly outside Canada? – No
    6. Is the IPP intellectual property being supplied to a non-resident that is not registered for the GST/HST? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Zero-rated.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 10 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLE:

    A Canadian company sells the international rights to operate a global database to a foreign company who pays the royalties to the Canadian company. As the recipient of the supply is a non-resident that is not registered for the GST/HST, the supply of such rights is zero-rated.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    4. Can the IPP be used in Canada? – Yes
    5. Does the IPP relate to real property situated outside Canada, to tangible personal property ordinarily situated outside Canada or to a service to be performed wholly outside Canada? – No
    6. Is the IPP intellectual property being supplied to a non-resident that is not registered for the GST/HST? – No

    RESULT:

    The supply does not qualify as a zero-rated export of IPP. Unless the supply is either zero-rated or exempt for a different reason, the GST/HST rate to apply will depend on the place of supply.

    REFERENCE:

    Section 10 of Part V of Schedule VI to the Excise Tax Act

    EXAMPLES:

    1. The right to use a membership is not zero-rated as an export of IPP because it is not intellectual property.
    2. The supply of intellectual property to a non-resident is not zero-rated as an export of IPP if that non-resident recipient is registered for the GST/HST.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Importing and exporting
    2. How is the supply being made? – Exports
    3. What is being exported? – Intangible personal property (for example, intellectual property)
    4. Can the IPP be used in Canada? – No

    RESULT:

    No GST/HST is charged for the supply because this type of supply is considered to be made outside Canada.

    REFERENCE:

    Paragraph 142(2)(c) of the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity

    Which best describes the charity's activity?

    Most supplies by charities are GST/HST exempt. Although, for income tax purposes, "charity” means a registered charity or a registered Canadian amateur athletic association, for GST/HST purposes, "charity" does not include a charity that is also:

    • a school authority
    • a public college
    • a university
    • a hospital authority, or
    • a local authority determined to be a municipality by the Minister of National Revenue.
    Instead, public institution is the term for that type of charity. For the tax status of supplies by a public institution, see the subtopic "Municipality, university, school or hospital"

    • Admission
    • Real property
    • Exported supply
    • Supply deemed to be made by the charity
    • Purely cosmetic service to an individual
    • Property or services supplied for direct cost
    • Personal property that was used in a commercial activity
    • Section 178.7, specified service supplied to a registrant
    • All or substantially all supplies made for no consideration
    • Other supplies that qualify for zero-rating under Schedule VI
    • Right to play or participate in a game of chance (other than an admission)
    • Sale of personal property or a service in the course of a fundraising activity
    • Lease of personal property in conjunction with an exempt lease of real property by the charity
    • Supplies of performing artists to a person who makes taxable supplies admissions for the performance
    • Food, beverages or short-term accommodation supplied to relieve poverty, suffering or distress of individuals
    • Membership (or other right) entitling person to supervision or instruction in recreational or athletic activity
    • None of the above
    • Food or beverages supplied under a program to seniors, underprivileged individuals or individuals with a disability
    • Tangible personal property acquired, manufactured or produced by the charity for the purpose of making a sale of the property
    • Supply of designated municipal property, if the charity is a person designated to be a municipality for the purposes of section 259 of the Excise Tax Act
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission

    What is the admission in respect of?

    • Admission to a fund-raising event
    • Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    • Place of amusement and the admission cost is not more than $1
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Admission to a fund-raising event

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt where:
    • the supply is of an admission to a fund-raising dinner, ball, concert, show or like fund-raising event, and
    • part of the consideration for the supply may reasonably be regarded as an amount that is donated to the charity and in respect of which a receipt referred to in subsection 110.1(2) or 118.1(2) of the Income Tax Act may be issued (or could be issued if the recipient of the supply were an individual)
    ACT:
    • Section 2 of Part V.1 of Sch V to Excise Tax Act
    • Subsections 110.1(2) and 118.1(2) of the Income Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1

    Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes

    Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
    5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes

    Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
    5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
    6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – Yes

    Is the game conducted in premises or at a place, including any temporary structure, that is used primarily for the purposes of conducting gambling activities?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
    5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
    6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – Yes
    7. Is the game conducted in premises or at a place, including any temporary structure, that is used primarily for the purposes of conducting gambling activities? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:
    Sections 1 and 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
    5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
    6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – Yes
    7. Is the game conducted in premises or at a place, including any temporary structure, that is used primarily for the purposes of conducting gambling activities? – No

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    ACT:
    Section 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
    5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – Yes
    6. Is the place of amusement either a bingo or a casino? – No

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    ACT:
    Section 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – Yes
    5. Are the functions (administrative, operating the game and taking the bets) performed exclusively by volunteers? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:
    Sections 1 and 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is more than $1
    4. Is the admission for a place of amusement whose principal activity is the placing of bets or the playing of games of chance? – No

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:
    Sections 1 and 6 of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Admission
    3. What is the admission in respect of? – Place of amusement and the admission cost is not more than $1

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt

    ACT:
    Paragraph 1(e) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property

    Which best describes the charity's supply of real property?

    • Sale of a residential complex
    • Supply of real property when a section 211 election is in effect
    • Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
    • Sale of real property recently used primarily in commercial activities of the charity
    • Sale of real property (that is not a residential complex) to an individual or a personal trust
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex

    Which best describes the residential property being sold?

    • Newly built home
    • Used owner-occupied home
    • Substantially renovated home
    • Mixed-used property (home and business)
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
    4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Newly built home

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:
    • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
    • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA does not exempt the sale of a home by a builder 

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
    4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Used owner-occupied home

    RESULT:

    GST/HST exempt when sold by someone other than the builder (even though the sale of a residential complex is removed from the general exempting provision that is specifically for charities). If substantial renovations have been completed, see the topic "Substantially renovated home" instead.
     
    ACT:
    • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA
    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
    4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Substantially renovated home

    DEFINITION:

    Substantial renovation - is generally when all of the interior of the existing building has been virtually removed or replaced (in other words, gutted) and, upon completion, the renovated or altered building is, or forms part of, a residential complex.

    RESULT:
    Generally taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:
    • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
    • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA excludes the sale of a home by a builder from its GST/HST exemption
    • Subsection 123(1) of the ETA defines "builder"
    • Subsection 190(1) of the ETA deems a person that has substantially renovated a house to be a builder (in the most common circumstances)

    REFERENCE:
    • GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales
    • GST/HST Memorandum 19.2 - Residential real property

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of a residential complex
    4. Which best describes the residential property being sold? – Mixed-used property (home and business)

    RESULT:

    The sale of the residential portion is deemed to be a separate supply than the remaining portion of the real property (for example, commercial real property). The general exemption available to charities excludes certain supplies of real property. However, if the either the residential or non-residential portion would have been exempt when sold on its own, it will be exempt when sold together with taxable real property.

    ACT:
    • Paragraph 1(j) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA) excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
    • Paragraph 1(l) of Part V.1 of Schedule V excludes the sale of a residential complex from the general exemption available to charities
    • Subsection 136(2) of the ETA
    • Section 2 of Part I of Schedule V to the ETA

    REFERENCE:
    GST/HST Memorandum 19.2.1 - Residential real property - Sales

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Supply of real property when a section 211 election is in effect

    RESULT:

    GST/HST taxable

    ACT:
    • Paragraph 1(m) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Section 211 of the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement

    Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital?

    NOTE:

    If a charity supplies, for consideration, a parking space by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement in the course of a business they carry on, paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act removes the supply from its general GST/HST exemption for charities if:
    • at the time the supply is made, it is reasonable to expect that the specified parking area will be used, during that calendar year, primarily by individuals who are accessing a property of, or a facility or establishment operated by, a particular person that is a municipality, a school authority, a hospital authority, a public college or a university, and
    • any of the following conditions is met:
      • under the governing documents of the charity, the charity is expected to use a significant part of its income or assets for the benefit of one or more of those particular persons referred to above in the first bullet
      • the charity and any of those particular persons have entered into one or more agreements with each other or with other persons in respect of the use of parking spaces by the individuals referred to in the first bullet above
      • any particular person referred to in the first bullet above performs any function or activity in respect of supplies by the charity of parking spaces in the specified parking area in relation to the supply
    However, being removed from the general exemption only makes the supply taxable if there is no other exempting provision. Section 7 of Part V.1 of Schedule V exempts certain types of supplies of a parking space by a charity that are made by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement and relate to access to a public hospital.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
    4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes

    For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital?

    Specified parking area for a parking space means all of the parking spaces that could be chosen for use in parking under the agreement for the supply of the parking space if all of those parking spaces were vacant and none were reserved for specific users.

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
    4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
    5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes

    Are all or substantially all of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
    4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
    5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
    6. Are all or substantially all of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    ACT:
    • Paragraph 1(o) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the Excise Tax Act (ETA)
    • Subparagraph 7(b)(i) of Part V.1 of Schedule V to the ETA

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
    4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
    5. For the specified parking area, is it either reasonable to expect that it will be used, during the calendar year in which the supply is made, primarily by individuals who are accessing a public hospital, or are all of its parking spaces reserved for use by individuals who are accessing a public hospital? – Yes
    6. Are all or substantially all of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No

    Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity?

    • Yes
    • No
    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Parking space in a parking lot by way of lease, licence or similar arrangement
    4. Does the parking space relate to access to a public hospital? – Yes
    5.     6. Are all or substantially all of the parking spaces in the specified parking area reserved for use by persons other than individuals accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – No
    7. Is the supply (or the amount of the consideration for the supply) conditional on the parking space being used by a person other than an individual accessing a public hospital otherwise than in a professional capacity? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%

    Was a section 211 election made by the charity in effect for the property where the parking space is situated?

    • Yes
    • No

    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property

    5.     9. Was a section 211 election made by the charity in effect for the property where the parking space is situated? – Yes

    RESULT:

    Taxable at 5%, 13% or 15%. The time period for the election being in effect refers to the time that tax would become payable if the supply were taxable.

    1. Which best describes the business activity? – Finished - Charity
    2. Which best describes the charity's activity? – Real property
    3. Which best describes the charity's supply of real property? – Sale of real property recently used primarily in commercial activities of the charity

    RESULT:

    GST/HST taxable where, immediately before the time tax would first become payable in respect of the sale if the sale were taxable, the property is used (otherwise than in making the sale) primarily in commercial activities of the charity
